note.p: This document is letter number 10 from a man named William B. Anderson that he wrote to his wife, Louisa in September of 1862 from Cincinnati. In all, there were 26 letters written to Louisa from 1862 to 1864. This particular letter is 2 pages long and is written on loose paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 9.0 inches tall, lined with blue horizontal lines. The first page of the letter is in pretty good condition. However, there are numerous brown stains that could possibly be dirt. The second page of the letter is in slightly better condition, with only a few smudges. Both pages seem to have been folded, twice long ways and once shorts ways. While the ink is black and legible throughout, there are still errors both in spelling and with ink smudges. The paper William used is a cream color.

projectDesc.p: William B. Anderson, in this letter dated September 28, 1862, continues his conversations with his wife Louisa as he has been doing since his first letter in June of 1862. In all, his 26 letters were written over a span of 3 years, all of these letters being housed in The Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University. In this letter, William addresses his wife with the typical things that he has been conversing with her in the past few months. He speaks about the battles occurring during this hard time of the American Civil War. With only one main reference to the war, the rest of his letter addresses domestic problems and affairs as well as economic affairs. He continues to ask how his wife and children are doing as well as his wife's mother. This is something that is important to William and shows his dedication to his family life. As far as economic matters, William tell his wife of money that is to be made by himself as well as how she should assess and take care of certain economic situations at home while he is away. He ends with his longing to come home and join Louisa and the children, and tries to assure her that he will be back soon.

This letter, written in 1862 in the city of Cincinnati (Cin), shows where Anderson was based most of the time, as almost all of the 26 letters are inscribed with Cincinnati in the dateline. This letter does not have any special notes as far as location. We know that there is fighting in the area, and that he is writing to his wife back home in Pittsburgh.

This letter continues to show how Anderson longs to be home with his wife and children, yet knows that he has no control over it at times. However, he does seem to want to stay around because he is getting paid very well. He tells Louisa at the end of the letter, "if I can only get what I now get and have health I would like to stay here a good while." He wants to make as much money as he so that when he goes home finally, he will have enough money to support his wife and kids without worry.

It is important to note that, although there do seem to be a few spelling errors and text that is difficult to read, William only crosses out one word. It does not seem as if he is in much of a hurry at this point in the letters. While we know that he would go on to write 16 more letters after his letter, he may have not known how long he was going to be away from his wife and children. As stated earlier, he is talking of coming home already, so at this point he may be writing as if he will see Louisa very soon.

While we can look at many factors regarding the actual letters and how they came about and are still in good condition in the Ohio State Rare Books and Manuscripts Library in Columbus, Ohio, we must, at some point, take the time to give thanks and credit to William B. Anderson himself writing these wonderful letters to his wife and for his wife for keeping them. In Scrolling Forward: Making Sense of Documents in the Digital Age, David M. Levy writes, "(A letter) carries a message from one individual to another; it addresses a highly personal subject; and in its hand-produced marks it expresses some of the drama and the pathos of the situation in which it is embedded" (80-81). William Anderson did not have to write these letters to his wife during the war and Louisa did not have to save them and preserve them through time. They both did their part, however, and people who view these letters today are now a part of their lives and can at least have a glimpse into what it was like to live when they did and how they did.
Levy, David M. Scrolling Forward: Making Sense of Documents in the Digital Age. New York: Arcade, 2001.

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of the Anderson letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription, with supplemental information allowing for semi-modernized, corrected, regularized, or expanded views included as the values of attributes associated with various elements. Accordingly, abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underscoring, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed or tagged as they appear in the original manuscripts. Regularized versions of all names and referring strings have been encoded as the values of "reg" attributes. Standard format values for all dates have been encoded in "value" attributes.

Corrections and emendations in Anderson's hand have been encoded as cancelations and interlinear or marginal additions. In a few cases, omitted text has been supplied by the editors for the sake of clarity and encoded with the TEI <supplied> element.

The following structural elements of the letters are also encoded: opener (including salutation and dateline), body, lines, paragraphs, pages, and closers (including salutation and signature). Notes and postscripts are identified as such.
The critical apparatus used in particular views of the letters is explained at the bottom of each view.

refsDecl.p: The XML files that constitute this edition of the William B. Anderson letters are named according the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: WBA_YYYYMMDD.xml. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars. If the year, month, or date on which a letter was written could not be determined, the appropriate part of the filename is rendered with 0s. XSL style sheet documents are named with the prefix "WBA" followed by an underscore and a descriptive phrase (e.g., "WBA_diplomatic.xsl).

In general, this edition follows the Text Encoding Initiative's Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, XML-compatible edition P4. For more information about TEI P4, see http://www.tei-c.org/P4X/. To facilitate embedding or linking to image, audio, and video files, this edition supplements the Text Encoding Initiative's DTD by adding a URL attribute to the <xref> element and an MMID (i.e., Media Manager ID) attribute to the <pb> element. The values of the MMID attribute in <pb> elements and the file IDs in the URL attribute of <xref> elements that link to, or embed, image, audio, and video files contained in the Media Manager are generated by the Media Manager application.

div1.p: William B Anderson tells his wife how he must take soldiers to Augusta, Kentucky. Anderson reports that he is doing well and that he is happy to hear that his wife's mother is also doing well. He wants his wife to take care of herself and the children. He describes when he thinks he may be home and for his wife to take care of the house and the work that needs to be done.
Previous letter 17 September 1862 Next letter 07 October 1862

I am ordered to take up
a lot of Soldiers to Augusta 3 Ky as the
Rebels have taken that place and Burned
it we are to take up a lot of men and
land them Below to attract and whip
the Rebels if they can I will land
a good piece Below too as I don’t want
shot. I will write a full acct on our
return I have no time to write much now,
your Mother 4 was here yesterday and is well
I am well & Hope you and all the children 5
are well take good care of your Health
and that of the children. I wrote you
a long letter a few days ago I recd.
yours yesterday and am sorry that Willie 6
is not well but hope he will soon recover
give my respects to all and write
often and longer I yesterday learned what
we are to get for our Boat and my
Portions is forty Dollars clear each day
say nothing about it I hope to stay here
Some time yet

P.S. We got our Coal found us and one
Hundred & Fifty Dolls per Day for the whole Boat
as we have not got steam up I will
write on. in your Letter you said that the
man was there to assess the Buggy I suppose
the calculation is to lay a heavy tax on
it as we Keep it for our own use all
right I will get it with interest back out
of Uncle Sam while I am here if all goes
well. I suppose Mr Walsh 7 might as well
Hole what potatoes you want dont want
in the Cellar down in the field where they
are and secure them by a fence around there
and Keep the Cows from there where he pastures
the Stalks. You can manage things the best
way you think till I come I cannot tell
when I will be back home now but may
accidentally get home sooner that I look
for I will it has the appearance of rain this
morning and if water comes to let larger Boats
run there we are done here and home I will go
you cannot Sensure me for being so indifferent
as appearing so indifferent about home when
you know what I am to get for staying away
if I can only get what I now get and have
health I would like to stay here a good
while and then when I go home to stay there
the Bal of my days I will stop so good
Bie write soon and give all the news
and Kiss the children
div1.closer:
Yours ever
WBA
Excuse all ever as I am in haste

div1.head: Notes
div1.note: 1. Cincinnati is a city in the extreme SW of Ohio. It was incorporated as a state in 1819 and is on the Ohio River bordering Kentucky. Enclyclopedia.com
2. William Anderson married his wife, Mary Louisa Fischgens in Cincinnati in 1853. She was born in Pittsburg and had 5 children with William. History of Allegheny County
3. Augusta is a city in Bracken County, Kentucky, along the Ohio River. Wikipedia.com
4. Louisa (Fischgens) Anderson's mother is named Ann (Woolslayer) Fischgens, born in Pittsburgh. History of Allegheny County
5. William B. Anderson and his wife Louisa, had 5 children: William Y, Anna M, John L, Robert, and Harry C. History of Allegheny County

6. While the name Willie is an undetermined person in Anderson's life, it could possibly be short for William Y, who was William's son, born in 1855, and who could have possibly been sick at the time of this letter. History of Allegheny County
7. Walsh is an undetermined person in Anderson's life.
